verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:135
verses.text: How then could Christ be celebrated by prophets and apostles as "the first begotten of the dead?" For if the Christ is believed to be the first begotten of the dead, He is the first begotten of the dead as having risen before all others.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:136
verses.text: But Moses appeared to the apostles before Christ suffered, having this form in which you say the resurrection is fulfilled.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:137
verses.text: Hence then, there is no resurrection of the form without the flesh.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:138
verses.text: For either there is a resurrection of the form as you teach, and then Christ is no longer "the first begotten of the dead," from the fact that souls appeared before Him, having this form after death; or He is truly the first begotten, and it is quite impossible that any should have been thought meet for a resurrection before Him, so as not to die again.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:139
verses.text: But if no one arose before Him, and Moses and Elias appeared to the apostles not having flesh, but only its appearance, the resurrection in the flesh is clearly manifested.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:140
verses.text: For it is most absurd that the resurrection should be set forth only in form, since the souls, after their departure from the flesh, never appear to lay aside the form which, he says, rises again.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:141
verses.text: But if that remains with them, so that it cannot be taken away, as with the soul of Moses and Elias; and neither perishes, as you think, nor is destroyed, but is everywhere present with them; then surely that form which never fell cannot be said to rise again.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:142
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:143
verses.text: But if any one, finding this inadmissible, answers, But how then, if no one rose before Christ went down into Hades, are several recorded as having risen before Him? Among whom is the son of the widow of Sarepta, and the son of the Shunammite, and Lazarus.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:144
verses.text: We must say: These rose to die again; but we are speaking of those who shall never die after their rising.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:145
verses.text: And if any one should speak doubtfully concerning the soul of Elias, as that the Scriptures say that he was taken up in the flesh, and we say that he appeared to the apostles divested of the flesh, we must say, that to allow that he appeared to the apostles in the flesh is more in favour of our argument.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:146
verses.text: For it is shown by this case that the body is susceptible of immortality, as was also proved by the translation of Enoch.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:147
verses.text: For if he could not receive immortality, he could not remain in a state of insensibility so long a time.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:148
verses.text: If, then, he appeared with the body, that was truly after he was dead, but certainly not as having arisen from the dead.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:149
verses.text: And this, we may say, if we agree with Origen when he says that the same form is given to the soul after death; when it is separated from the body, which is of all things the most impossible, from the fact that the form of the flesh was destroyed before by its changes, as also the form of the melted statue before its entire dissolution.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:150
verses.text: Because the quality cannot be separated from the material, so as to exist by itself; for the shape which disappears around the brass is separated from the melted statue, and has not longer a substantial existence.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:151
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:152
verses.text: Since the form is said to be separated in death from the flesh, come, let us consider in how many ways that which is separated is said to be separated.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:153
verses.text: Now a thing is said to be separated from another either in act and subsistence, or in thought; or else in act, but not in subsistence.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:154
verses.text: As if, for instance, one should separate from each other wheat and barley which had been mingled together; in as far as they are separated in motion, they are said to be separated in act; in as far as they stand apart when separated, they are said to be separated in subsistence.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:155
verses.text: They are separated in thought when we separate matter from its qualities, and qualities from matter; in act, but not in subsistence, when a thing separated from another no longer exists, not having a substantive existence.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:156
verses.text: And it may be observed that it is so also in mechanics, when one looks upon a statue or a brazen horse melted.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:157
verses.text: For, when he considers these things, he will see their natural form changing; and they alter into another figure from which the original form disappears.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:158
verses.text: For if any one should melt down the works formed into the semblance of a man or a horse, he will find the appearance of the form disappearing, but the material itself remaining.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:159
verses.text: It is, therefore, untenable to say, that the form shall arise in nowise corrupted, but that the body in which the form was stamped shall be destroyed.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:160
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:161
verses.text: But he says that it will be so; for it will be changed in a spiritual body.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:162
verses.text: Therefore, it is necessary to confess that the very same form as at first does not arise, from its being changed and corrupted with the flesh.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:163
verses.text: For although it be changed into a spiritual body, that will not be properly the original substance, but a certain resemblance of it, fashioned in an ethereal body.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:164
verses.text: If, however, it is not the same form, nor yet the body which arises, then it is another in the place of the first.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:165
verses.text: For that which is like, being different from that which it resembles, cannot be that very first thing in accordance with which it was made.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:166
verses.text: XVII.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:167
verses.text: Moreover, he says that that is the appearance or form which shows forth the identity of the members in the distinctive character of the form.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:168
verses.text: XVIII.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:169
verses.text: And, when Origen allegorises that which is said by the prophet Ezekiel concerning the resurrection of the dead, and perverts it to the return of the Israelites from their captivity in Babylon, the saint in refuting him, after many other remarks, says this also: For neither did they obtain a perfect liberty, nor did they overcome their enemies by a greater power, and dwell again in Jerusalem; and when they frequently intended to build (the temple), they were prevented by other nations.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:170
verses.text: Whence, also, they were scarce able to build that in forty-six years, which Solomon completed from the foundations in seven years.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:171
verses.text: But what need we say on this subject? For from the time of Nebuchadnezzar, and those who after him reigned over Babylon, until the time of the Persian expedition against the Assyrians, and the empire of Alexander, and the war which was stirred up by the Romans against the Jews, Jerusalem was six times overthrown by its enemies.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:172
verses.text: And this is recorded by Josephus, who says: "Jerusalem was taken in the second year of the reign of Vespasian.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:173
verses.text: It had been taken before five times; but now for the second time it was destroyed.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:174
verses.text: For Asochaeus, king of Egypt, and after him Antiochus, next Pompey, and after these Sosius, with Herod, took the city and burnt it; but before these, the king of Babylon conquered and destroyed it".

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:175
verses.text: XIX.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:176
verses.text: He says that Origen holds these opinions which he refutes.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:177
verses.text: And there may be a doubt concerning Lazarus and the rich man.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:178
verses.text: The simpler persons think that these things were spoken as though both were receiving their due for the things which they had done in life in their bodies; but the more accurate think that, since no one is left in life after the resurrection, these things do not happen at the resurrection.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:179
verses.text: For the rich man says: "I have five brethren;…lest they also come into this place of torment," send Lazarus, that he may tell them of those things which are here.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:180
verses.text: And, therefore, if we ask respecting the "tongue," and the "finger," and "Abraham's bosom," and the reclining there, it may perhaps be that the soul receives in the change a form similar in appearance to its gross and earthly body.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:181
verses.text: If, then, any one of those who have fallen asleep is recorded as having appeared, in the same way he has been seen in the form which he had when he was in the flesh.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:182
verses.text: Besides, when Samuel appeared, it is clear that, being seen, he was clothed in a body; and this must especially be admitted, if we are pressed by arguments which prove that the essence of the soul is incorporeal, and is manifested by itself.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:183
verses.text: But the rich man in torment, and the poor man who was comforted in the bosom of Abraham, are said, the one to be punished in Hades, and the other to be comforted in Abraham's bosom, before the appearing of the Saviour, and before the end of the world, and therefore before the resurrection; teaching that now already, at the change, the soul rises a body.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:184
verses.text: Wherefore, the saint says as follows: Setting forth that the soul, after its removal hence, has a form similar in appearance to this sensitive body; does Origen represent the soul, after Plato, as being incorporeal? And how should that which, after removal from the world, is said to have need of a vehicle and a clothing, so that it might not be found naked, be in itself other than incorporeal? But if it be incorporeal, must it not also be incapable of passion? For it follows, from its being incorporeal, that it is also impassible and imperturbable.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:185
verses.text: If, then, it was not distracted by any irrational desire, neither was it changed by a pained or suffering body.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:186
verses.text: For neither can that which is incorporeal sympathize with a body, nor a body with that which is incorporeal, if, indeed, the soul should seem to be incorporeal, in accordance with what has been said.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:187
verses.text: But if it sympathize with the body, as is proved by the testimony of those who appear, it cannot be incorporeal.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:188
verses.text: Therefore God alone is celebrated, as the unbegotten, independent, and unwearied nature; being incorporeal, and therefore invisible; for "no man hath seen God".

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:189
verses.text: But souls, being rational bodies, are arranged by the Maker and Father of all things into members which are visible to reason, having received this impression.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:190
verses.text: Whence, also, in Hades, as in the case of Lazarus and the rich man, they are spoken of as having a tongue, and a finger, and the other members; not as though they had with them another invisible body, but that the souls themselves, naturally, when entirely stripped of their covering, are such according to their essence.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:191
verses.text: XX.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:192
verses.text: The saint says at the end: The words, "For to this end Christ both died, and rose, and revived, that He might be Lord both of the dead and living," must be taken as referring to souls and bodies; the souls being the living, as being immortal, and the bodies being dead.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:193
verses.text: XXI.

verses.name: Methodius: On the Resurrection 4:194
verses.text: Since the body of man is more honourable than other living creatures, because it is said to have been formed by the hands of God, and because it has attained to be the vehicle of the reasonable soul; how is it that it is so short-lived, shorter even than some of the irrational creatures? Is it not clear that its long-lived existence will be after the resurrection?.
